review_title: One of the best movie from bollywood
Unmeaningful, overacted and underwritten youth story
review_detailed_main:
Stardom can achieve a lot in India. Apart from convincing masses to buy various products, it can turn dud scripts into blockbusters. Ayan Mukherjee tells us something about the youth, yet again after 'Wake up Sid'. Is he representing the current generation? Is he out to inspire them? Does he have an undying message in the life and travels of Bunny Thapar? Disappointingly, it is none of the above. 'Yeh Jawani Hai Deewani' rides on the back of Ranbir Kapoor who at times, appears lost in bland scenes and tries hard in others to put life in them. The anguish can be felt by some of the audience and instantly they can conclude that this melodramatic, cheesy and inebriated representation of a non-existent class of youth is just over-the-top.

The wafer thin plot revolves around Bunny's (Ranbir Kapoor) aspirations of carefree world travel. Not only does he have to convince his father (Farooq Shaikh) to let him live his dream but he must then tolerate his friends, the loud and indecisive Avi (Aditya Roy Kapoor) who has some occasional funny dialogue and Aditi (Kalki Koechlin), who was frankly better off in Kashyap's realistic films since the fake vibe she carries is terribly unconvincing. Then of course, they take a 'make-my-trekking-trip' to Manali, joined by the studious Naina (spectacled Deepika Padukone) who must awkwardly endure the games, flirting, drinking and street fighting that the others so happily indulge in. Thereafter, Bunny travels abroad for his education and career, without much happening in that phase apart from solitary moments of photography, random hook-ups and pensive introspection. Then suddenly, he gets a video invite to Aditi's wedding in Udaipur where they are all back to flirting, drinking, fighting and a lot more dancing this time.

"I want to fly, I want to run, I even want to fall but I don't want to stop"... at the surface, Bunny's philosophy is alluring but without the backing of a script to support it, those lines just fade away into drunken indulgence. On one hand he claims to enjoy his way of life and on the other, being love struck, his conviction melts in a lip-lock scene. His dilemma is his weakness and perhaps the film's major drawback.

The immaturity and inaneness of several scenes contribute to the incredulity of Mukherjee's script. Now he leads the folks of small towns and villages to believe that city-dwellers are a part of this cool culture where girls call each other 'dudes' and a guy addresses a girl as 'Man'. To add to that, the pahadi folks would feel miserable about their own lives knowing that city people can hike up the snowy peaks while being dressed for a party, drinking along the way, listening to their music on large headphones and then discover German mountaineer parties over the next hill. The other harsh reality that is uncovered by Mukherjee's vision is that as you start traveling around the world, you tend to grow an ugly beard because you don't have to give a damn.

Eventually though, Mukherjee gives rise to the much needed maturity in the film when Bunny and Naina struggle to relate to each others' lives and conclude that "tum galat nahi ho, sirf alag ho". Only if the conclusion of it all had been along those lines, the film would have been more realistic and meaningful.

Ranbir Kapoor rides the film on his shoulders. As versatile a dancer that he is, Ranbir also pulls off comedy, tragedy, indifference and seriousness with equal credibility. With just a handful of memorable dialogues, his potential hasn't been realized by Mukherjee and to make it worse, the supporting cast does not match up to his level. Kalki Koechlin was impressive in Anurag Kashyap's films but she seems quite out of place here. The first half of the movie is overacted with loudness that gets irritating. Aditya Roy Kapoor too tends to be louder than required and is reduced to the most poorly written character in the movie. Farooq Shaikh extended a favor to the director by taking up his role which wasn't worthy of such a fine actor. Deepika Padukone still struggles with the simplest of roles and tries to drive attention to her skimpy clothing rather than expressing various emotions. Her spontaneity may have improved but versatility and credibility of her character are still lacking. The true star of the film however, is Manali and its surrounding snowy scenery. The Himalayas have seldom been depicted in such spectacular fashion and the scene on the mountain top is awe inspiring (only to be spoiled by Ranbir's unnecessary screaming).

There are too many songs by Pritam in this Deewani Jawani. Balam Pichkari is a catchy holi song while the Madhuri Dixit Via Agra track is forgettable. Kabira is melodious but reminiscent of Iktara. Badtameez Dil is fun to watch with some excellent choreography and upbeat tunes.

Ayan Mukherjee's attempt at portraying the lifestyles and challenging relationships of today's youth had some foundation but lost its way in the cheesy, incredulous delivery of the script. Too many fake characters delineate little more than indulgence in alcohol, women and the carefree attitudes. Zoya Akhtar's take on such a subject was far superior (ZNMD) in every aspect with depth in its story, characters and the exemplary direction. 'Yeh Jawani Hai Deewani' is just not meaningful enough for the viewer to care about the characters or story. Too much of it was over-the-top from the beginning to recover its credibility. Add to that, the occasional overacting and numerous songs that put brakes on an already struggling story-line. Bunny's character seems determined to live life his own way at times but still seems confused and uncertain about the long run. If that was the point of Mukherjee's film, then it should have been titled 'Wake up Bunny'.

review_title: Ain't a masterpiece, but if you're new to Bollywood, this is where to start...
review_detailed_main:
Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani (stylized as YJHD) is the routine Bollywood romantic-comedy-drama, with the backdrop of travel. It has all the elements of a typical Bollywood romance that you'd probably expect from Shah Rukh Khan, another Bollywood actor known as the 'King of Romance' in India. There's romance, bromance, bonding, as well as some drama.

Heck, I'd call this a slight rehash of DDLJ (Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge), one of the most successful Bollywood films worldwide. But DDLJ is almost 20 years ago. This is a modern update on the story, catered for the audiences of today.

It has a great emotional angle to it, without the melodrama. If you see the film, you'll probably know what I mean. Also, the chemistry between the lead pair Ranbir Kapoor and Deepika Padukone is downright FIERY, and Deepika wildly excels in her subtle yet meaningful and deep performance as the introvert Naina.

The dialogue is hilarious at times, and the movie has it share of well- written scenes, which almost perfectly depict every character's emotions. The music is simply grand.

YJHD isn't all that ambitious, and may seem like a bit of a departure from director Ayan Mukherji's last directorial venture, Wake Up Sid. But for those of you reading this review and are not living in India, you should really start with this film, if you want to check out some of Bollywood.

Great performances, simple story, fiery song-and-dance sequences, funny lines, and a romantic soul, YJHD is a fine successor to DDLJ, for the youth.

review_title: A lovely coming of age movie

review_detailed_main:
YEH JAWAANI HAI DEEWANI (Movie Review)

ONE LINER:

Badtameez Dil Maane Na..!!

EXPECTATIONS:

Expectations were high from the very start. KARAN JOHAR production, AYAN MUKERJEE coming after WAKE UP SID, RANBIR KAPOOR with DEEPIKA. ADITYA ROY KAPOOR after AASHIQUI2. Everything was making it more to top. Music worked big time. Expectations rose day by day... And a Huge hype was there.

VIEWS:

1. For me YJHD is much more then my expectations.

2. Total Fun total entertaining. The most fresh movie after ZINDAGI NA MILEGI DOBARA and at various occasions in first half ZNMD comes to mind..

3. Beautiful Direction with good script and good dialogues..

4. Cinematography was top notch..

5. Music works totally with the movie. A total enjoyable music.

6. Chemistry of the lead pair RANBIR KAPOOR and DEEPIKA is just brilliant.. They seemed extra comfortable with each other.

7. All the characters were well defined and none was unnecessary even if it was for few seconds too.

8. First half is just Mind blowing carrying full ratings.. Its the second half which has problem and that is , it is dragged and pace becomes slow at spots but overall a good second half too.

9. A Friendship movie having romance, fun etc everything in it. Total YOUTHFUL.. YOUTH is loving it. But remaining all ages will love it too.

STORY & SCRIPT:

Story is very good. Script is beautiful. Screenplay is Too good . Dialogues are brilliant.

DIRECTION:

AYAN MUKERJEE rocks in his second outing after WAKE UP SID which was loved by many. But in my opinion this one is much better than that.. His direction is beautiful and mature.

MUSIC:

Music By PRITAM is total fun going with the movie and it becomes more catchy after seeing the movie. BALAM PICHKARI is the best of the lot. KABIRA is just excellent in the movie although I didn't enjoyed it much in audio hearings previously. Choreography of the songs is beautiful.

CASTING & ACTING:

RANBIR KAPOOR is without any doubt justified in superstar league. His hard work shows. His choice of movies is brilliant. He has acted beautifully again here.. It's His show totally. His acting His expressions, dialog delievery everything is great.. He is totally rocking.

DEEPIKA PADUKONE is just mind blowing. Her one of the career best acting. She is so beautiful in the movie and even acts beautifully. She is too too good. And lead pair chemistry is awesome.

ADITYA ROY KAPUR after AASHIQUI 2 is in complete form again. He rocks.. A great actor to look forward too.

KALKI surprisingly gives her career best here. At few places you cant believe that this is Her.

KUNAAL ROY KAPUR and FAROOQ SHEIKH are too good in their respective parts.

EVELYN SHARMA is total eye candy as her role demands..

Remaining actors OK.

PLUSSES & MINUSES:

PLUSSES:

1. Friendship, Love And Romance.

2. Music.

3. Actors.

4. Chemistry between lead actors.

5. Movie's Execution and direction, cinematography.

6. Freshness.

MINUSSES:

1. Few places pace drops in second half and it gets dragged in second half too.

2. Could have been trimmed easily 15 minutes..

CONCLUSION:

OVERALL a Total Fresh lovely Friendship movie with lot of fun, emotions, entertainment, everything.. Can't miss it watching in cinema. Go For It..

RATINGS: 8.5/10.

This is the first review I am writing for a bollywood movie. I believe this movie deserves one.

After reading reviews and keeping an eye on this movie for over a week, I was in two minds whether I should go watch this movie or not. There are so many negative reviews here that just make you think that this movie is going to be terrible and you should not have any good expectations before you go to watch this movie.

If you are a movie expert and pretty much watch every bollywood movie that comes out than you might not find this movie to be appealing. But if you are somewhat like me who occasionally watches good bollywood movies than I would recommend you go watch this and decide for yourself.

As other people have said, first half of movie is somewhat fast and is more funny compared to second half. Second half gets more emotional and reflects typical Indian love stories. But that does not mean that second half deserves to get 2/10. I would rate first half 8/10 and second half 7/10.

All the songs in the movie are really good and most of them relate to the movie very well. Only thing you might find a bit strange is Madhuri's role in the movie and that song at the start.

If you are a fan of Ranbir/Deepika, this movie is a must for you. Both of them have done a really good job. Many people criticized the acting but I personally don't think there is anything wrong with it. We go to watch a movie to enjoy it not to bite down on every possible little detail and find mistakes and errors. No movie is perfect and to me this is very good.

There are few things to note if you are going to watch the movie with family/kids. Movie itself is not bad but there are few dirty jokes/talk and some kissing scenes. Other than that there is no rude language.

I watched a bollywood movie in the cinema after a long time and really enjoyed it. I would say if you are not sure about this movie give it a try. Just keep in mind this may not be your favorite but it certainly won't be the worst you've seen.

review_title: A Very Good Entertainer From Ranbir-Deepika
review_detailed_main:
I watched this 3 months after the release and i must say that it isn't as bad as everyone has made it out to be. I agree its a plot that has been used in Bollywood many times, but the way Ayaan Mukurjee executes this is very different from your usual Bollywood films.

The plot centres a group of friends which includes Aditi (Kalki Koechlin) Avi (Aditya Roy Kapoor) and Kabir Thapar (Bunny) (ranbir Kapoor), who all ready to take a rec around manila. Naina (Deepika Padukone) plays a geeky, quirky middle class Indian girl who's only dream is to live like others, she gets all this when she joins Bunny and his gang on their rec to manila. The plot follows as all usual Hindi films usual do.

Ranbir Kapoor after Barfi gives a performance of a lifetime as the carefree Kabir, he plays the role as though he is Kabir himself which is why Ranbir in this moment in time is one of the leading stars of the industry. Deepika also gives a brilliant performance she goes from strength to strength with this role as Naina. Both main actors live the characters as though they are themselves. Aditya and Kalki add a bit of mas ala to the cast. Overall the main cast is very good and hats off to Ayaan and Karan for producing a story that has been told but in a modern style.

Overall a must watch for Ranbir-Deepika fans and overall Hindi movie lovers.

A journey that you must experience

review_title: Heartfelt romantic dramas with a touch of adventure and self-discovery
review_detailed_main:
Bollywood romantic drama Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani was released in 2013. Directed by Ayan Mukerji and produced by Karan Johar, the movie stars Ranbir Kapoor, Deepika Padukone, Aditya Roy Kapur, and Kalki Koechlin in lead roles. The film explores themes of friendship, love, ambition, and self-discovery.

The story revolves around four friends: Bunny (Ranbir Kapoor), Naina (Deepika Padukone), Avi (Aditya Roy Kapur), and Aditi (Kalki Koechlin), who meet during a trekking trip in the Himalayas. The movie traces their journey through various stages of life, from their carefree college days to their individual struggles and aspirations as adults. Bunny is an adventurous and ambitious guy who dreams of traveling the world, while Naina is a nerdy and introverted girl who gradually opens up to new experiences. The film explores their complex relationship, their unrequited love, and their paths crossing again after years of separation.

One of the highlights of "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is its beautiful cinematography, which captures the scenic landscapes of the Himalayas and other locations with great visual appeal. The film's music, composed by Pritam, is also a standout aspect, with several catchy and melodious tracks that became popular upon release.

The performances in the film are commendable, with Ranbir Kapoor delivering a charismatic portrayal of Bunny. He effortlessly transitions between the carefree and adventurous persona and the more mature and introspective side of his character. Deepika Padukone shines as Naina, effectively portraying her transformation from a shy and reserved girl to a confident and self-assured woman. Aditya Roy Kapur and Kalki Koechlin provide good support with their respective characters, adding depth to the narrative.

The screenplay strikes a good balance between light-hearted moments, emotional depth, and some thought-provoking dialogues. The film effectively explores the themes of friendship, love, and self-discovery, capturing the dilemmas and choices faced by the characters as they navigate through life.

However, one criticism of the film is its runtime, which stretches over three hours. Some viewers might find certain portions to be unnecessarily long, affecting the overall pacing of the narrative.

Overall, "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is an entertaining and visually appealing film that offers a mix of romance, drama, and comedy. It successfully portrays the journey of its characters, their relationships, and their pursuit of dreams. If you enjoy heartfelt romantic dramas with a touch of adventure and self-discovery, this movie is worth watching.

review_title: Dil Chahta Hai Wannabe Fails Miserably
review_detailed_main:
Once again, we have an example of new age Indian cinema which purports to be "different". In many ways, it is worse than the old school boy-meets-girl formula films of yore because one didn't walk in with the hope that some new ground may be explored.

We as viewers are expected to meet the aimless, destructive, misogynistic and homophobic protagonists and consider them lovable. Not.

We are supposed to consider their boorish behavior applaudable. Not.

Ranbir Kapoor who put in a fine show in Rocket Singh - Salesman of the Year seems to have decided that he no longer wants to act when hamming away is adequate. Pity! Deepika Padukone is utterly miscast as a woman with her head in books and unaware of her stunner looks.

Aditya Roy Kapoor as the resident lush and Kalki Koechlin as the bindaas gal are good but then the movie is not really about them.

This is the nth time that Hindi film directors have tried and failed to recapture the Dil Chahhta Hai sort of chemistry between protagonists. I just wish they would stop trying to be cool because they fail miserably.

A vibrant journey through love, friendship, and self-discovery, "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is a Bollywood coming-of-age film that leaves a lasting impression. Directed by Ayan Mukerji, the movie seamlessly blends romance, drama, and humor, offering a captivating narrative.

The film revolves around Bunny (Ranbir Kapoor), a spirited young man with a passion for travel and exploration, and Naina (Deepika Padukone), a studious medical student seeking to break free from her introverted shell. As their paths cross during a trek, the story unfolds, taking the audience on a rollercoaster ride of emotions.

One of the film's strengths lies in its well-developed characters, each with their own quirks and dreams. The chemistry between Ranbir Kapoor and Deepika Padukone is palpable, adding authenticity to the evolving dynamics of their relationship. The supporting cast, including Aditya Roy Kapur, Kalki Koechlin, and Kunaal Roy Kapur, brings humor and depth to the narrative.

The cinematography is visually stunning, capturing the picturesque landscapes of Manali and the grandeur of the destination wedding sequences. The film's soundtrack, composed by Pritam, is a mix of soulful melodies and energetic tracks, complementing the narrative and enhancing the overall viewing experience.

While "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" excels in portraying the excitement of youth and the complexities of relationships, there are moments where the pacing feels a bit stretched, particularly in the second half. However, the film's heartfelt moments and the chemistry between the lead actors make it a memorable cinematic experience.

In conclusion, "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is a joyous celebration of youth, love, and friendship. Ayan Mukerji's direction, coupled with stellar performances and a captivating soundtrack, makes it a film that resonates with audiences of all ages. Whether you're a fan of Bollywood romance or a sucker for scenic visuals, this film is a delightful exploration of the highs and lows of life's adventurous journey.

review_title: Good story and chemistry between Dips and Ranbir
review_detailed_main:
I'm watching this film well after it was released in the cinemas (in fact after seeing both Besharam and Chennai Express) so I know how the film had performed at the box office, and what most people thought of it so my expectations were high!

YJHD does through the typical roller coaster of a Bollywood romance, but where it differs from those that have failed, is that it has the star power of Ranbir and Deepika at the top of their game, alongside lovely music by Pritam and fantastic direction by Ayan Mukherjee.

Ayan is certainly one of the top young directors in the industry, and after Wake Up Sid, shows exactly why he holds his mantle piece. This work will go down as one of his finest, even though I am sure he will make many more films.

This role is bread and butter for someone of Ranbir's stature now. He eases into the role, initially playing the fun going flirty young man, then growing into the serious, yet romantic mature man later. This role is not on the same level as Barfi, there is no comparison, however it's these types of roles that will keep Ranbir competing with the likes of SRK for the romantic king award! Deepika has grown massively this year, and this being the third film (Ram Leela is the 4th) she has hit the industry with a bang in 2013. She looks stunning on screen and plays her role perfectly! Kalki, as annoying as her role, again plays it without any blemishes. Her role reminds you of Zindagi Na Milenge Dobara quite a lot! Aditya seems to be alcoholic of 2013 with this and Aashiqui 2 but does full justice to the role regardless!

review_title: Rambir Kapoor: The Runt Of Rishi's Litter.
review_detailed_main:
I don't know what the fuss was about this film. I decided to see it and was bored less than half-way through it. I have seen similar films about coming to age sexuality: Dil Hai Ki Manta Nahin, Jo Jeeta Wohi Sikander, Maine Pyaar Kiya, Hum Apke Hain Kaun?, Aashiqui(Original Rahul Roy film), Dil, Woh Saat Din, Ram Teri Ganga Maili, Saaweray Wali Gaadi(BEST ONE AND MUST SEE SUNNY DEOL FILM), Ek Duuje Ke Liye(TIMELESS CLASSIC ALSO MUST SEE), Lahme, Henna, Chandini, Saagar, Masterji, Prem Pratigya, Eeshwar, Saheb, Mili, Agar Tum Na Hote, Ghar, Veer Zaara(LATE YASH CHOPRA MASTERPIECE)..... The list goes on and on....

This film can be compared to rat turd. It really stinks!

The film is about a young teenager Naina (Deepika Paad-ukone Paad=Fart in Hindi or Gujarti for that matter...) leaving home against her parents wishes and going on a camping trip. There here womanhood wakens and she feels sexually drawn to another college-mate she knows called Bunny(The Runt Kapoor).

Eight years pass. Naina finishes medical school and works in a clinic. Bunny works as a television cameraman for travel shows and roams the world, as he had planned. They meet again in Udaipur, for Aditi's lavish wedding to Taran (Kunaal Roy Kapur), an awkward but adoring engineer. Naina and Bunny are again strongly attracted to each other. Both resist love – Bunny because he does not want to give up a dream job he has been offered (as a travel show host), Naina because she fears that Bunny will break her heart again. Will they find a way to be together? Spectacular dance numbers punctuate a roller-coaster romance. Only in the last few minutes of the film does love triumph.

Verdict: you're better off watching the above mentioned movies.

Though I'll admit that the story has a few clichés here and there that kept it from being better. Still, given that I was watching it while flying across the Atlantic, it was a nice time-passer and kept my attention.

The film begins with Naina and her mother meeting up with a rather vacuous old schoolmate of Naina. While Naina graduated top of her class and is at the top of her class in medical school, this meeting with the schoolmate left Naina feeling that she's missing something...fun. So, on a lark, she decides to drop everything and head off on an adventure--and she picks the same destination the vacuous schoolmate chose. There, Naina slowly learns to unwind and meets sexy Bunny (he is a man--not some furry--despite the name). They hit it off and seem to be falling in love but one HUGE problem stands in their way--Bunny has vowed never to marry and wants to travel the world and experience EVERYTHING. What's to happen? See the film.

Like the typical Bollywood film, this romance is predictable and there's lots of singing. You can't fault the film for.

Like all rom-coms, YEH JAWAANI HAI DEEWANI sparkles with romance, merriment and heartache, is brightly glossy and boasts of crackling chemistry between its lead actors, but Ayan makes sure the heady concoction never waters down. The best part is, he never borrows from romantic clichés that most love stories depend upon and that, in my opinion, is this film's biggest strength. Expect no unwanted melodrama, no unwelcome characters, no earsplitting background music to accentuate the proceedings... On the whole, YEH JAWAANI HAI DEEWANI is a revitalizing take on romance and relationships. A wonderful cinematic experience, this one should strike a chord with not just the youth, but cineastes of all age-groups.

review_title: An Ode to the Bunny inside us
review_detailed_main:
"Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is a vibrant and heartwarming romantic drama directed by Ayan Mukerji, released in 2013. Set against the backdrop of picturesque locations in India and abroad, the film explores themes of love, friendship, ambition, and self-discovery with a touch of nostalgia.

Plot and Execution:

The film follows the journey of Kabir Thapar, fondly called Bunny (played by Ranbir Kapoor), a carefree and ambitious young man who dreams of traveling the world and making a mark in the field of photography. His life takes a turn when he reunites with his old classmates during a trekking expedition in Manali. Bunny's encounter with Naina Talwar (played by Deepika Padukone), a shy and studious medical student, sparks a deep connection that transcends their contrasting personalities.

Strengths:

Chemistry and Performances:

Ranbir Kapoor and Deepika Padukone deliver charismatic performances as Bunny and Naina, respectively. Their on-screen chemistry is palpable and forms the emotional core of the film. Kapoor brings Bunny's restless spirit to life with charm and vulnerability, while Padukone portrays Naina's journey from introversion to self-assuredness with grace and depth.

Supporting Cast:

The ensemble cast, including Aditya Roy Kapur as Avi and Kalki Koechlin as Aditi, adds richness to the narrative. Aditi's exuberance and Avi's carefree attitude provide a perfect contrast to Bunny and Naina's evolving relationship, creating moments of laughter and reflection.

Visual Aesthetics:

Ayan Mukerji and cinematographer V. Manikandan capture the beauty of Manali, Udaipur, and other locations with stunning visuals. The picturesque landscapes, coupled with Pritam Chakraborty's soulful music, enhance the film's emotional depth and create a captivating visual experience.

Themes of Friendship and Growth:

"Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" celebrates the bond of friendship and the transformative power of love. The film explores how relationships evolve over time and the impact of personal choices on one's journey of self-discovery. The characters' dilemmas and aspirations resonate with viewers, making the narrative relatable and engaging.

Weaknesses:

Pacing Issues: While the film's narrative is engaging, some viewers may find certain sequences and subplots repetitive or stretched, affecting the overall pacing of the story.

Conclusion:

"Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is a refreshing blend of romance, drama, and coming-of-age elements that appeals to audiences across generations. Ayan Mukerji's adept direction, coupled with stellar performances and captivating visuals, makes this film a memorable cinematic experience.

The film's exploration of love, friendship, and personal growth resonates with viewers, offering moments of laughter, tears, and introspection. "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" remains a beloved Bollywood classic, celebrated for its relatable characters, memorable dialogues, and soulful music.

Overall, "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is a journey of emotions and aspirations, reminding us to cherish every moment, follow our dreams, and embrace the joy of living life to the fullest. It's a must-watch for anyone seeking a blend of romance, entertainment, and heartfelt storytelling in Indian cinema.

Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani: A Heartwarming Journey of Love and Friendship

Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is a delightful blend of romance, comedy, and life lessons that resonates deeply with anyone who's ever had dreams, fallen in love, or cherished friendships. Directed by Ayan Mukerji, the film beautifully captures the essence of youthful exuberance and the complexities of personal growth.

The story revolves around Naina Talwar (Deepika Padukone), an introverted medical student who embarks on a transformative journey to the Himalayas with her former classmates. The trip rekindles her friendship with the charming and adventurous Kabir "Bunny" Thapar (Ranbir Kapoor), the carefree Avi (Aditya Roy Kapur), and the vibrant Aditi (Kalki Koechlin). As Naina finds herself falling for Bunny, she faces the bittersweet realization that his dreams of wandering the world might never align with her hopes of a settled life.

Ranbir Kapoor shines as Bunny, bringing a charismatic energy to the role of a man torn between his wanderlust and newfound love. Deepika Padukone delivers a compelling performance as Naina, transitioning from a shy introvert to a confident woman. The chemistry between Ranbir and Deepika is palpable, adding depth to their evolving relationship.

The supporting cast, particularly Aditya Roy Kapur and Kalki Koechlin, add vibrant colours to the narrative. Aditya's portrayal of Avi, a fun-loving yet troubled friend, and Kalki's Aditi, who navigates her feelings and eventual maturity, are noteworthy.

The film's strength lies in its relatable characters and the message that life is about finding a balance between pursuing your dreams and valuing the relationships that shape you. The scenic cinematography, capturing the breathtaking landscapes of Manali and Udaipur, adds a visual treat to the emotional rollercoaster. However, the movie's length (2h 40m) might feel a bit stretched at times, and some scenes could have been crisper. Despite this, "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" remains a heartwarming film that emphasizes the importance of friendships and love while chasing one's dreams.

Overall, "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is a must-watch for its beautiful portrayal of relationships and the timeless lesson that while it's essential to follow your dreams, the journey is more fulfilling when shared with loved ones.

2. Music is great. Very cool and very hummable.

Ranbir-Deepika..the hottest pair of this decade. There was so much hype about this one,I wondered how mind blowing it would be. Then,the movie started. An hour into the movie and I could not figure out what was different about this one than the so many zillion formulaic movies made before..I could not think of one difference. Also,it's very lengthy,almost 3 hours. It felt like Ayan Mukherjee had to remind people he was still in the industry and he made a meaningless movie to prove this and he had an unlimited budget for this. Yes,the songs are great,the actors are too good and it's shot in very scenic locations,but it is the story or the absence of one that let me down. By the end of it,it felt like 4 great actors were thrown in front of the camera and asked to relive their earlier years. Nonetheless,it has a lot of dreamy content and it does make you feel good because of its good music and an unrealistic happy ending. Watch it if you're a big fan of the romantic genre.

Story line is confusing and so was makeup. 8 years didn't bring any difference to any of four major characters. One major character seem to have no roll at all. It is kind of sad mixture of two or three recent hit movies like Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara. Karan Johar should spent more time making movies rather having coffees. Songs are barely OK. Even Kabeera's lyrics let it down, although beautiful music to it. I am banging my head about what Aashqui 2 guy Aditya Roy Kapoor is doing in this movie. review_title: Watch it for Music, Ranbir and Deepika
review_detailed_main:
Yeh Jawani Hai Deewani-:A movie which does tickle you at times but never takes itself seriously,which might have been the best thing if those heavy messages weren't there.YJHD tries to be at multiple boats throughout its run time.A bit of ZNMD,flavour of Swades and portions of IHLS makes the whole of YJHD.

Ayan Mukherji who made the wonderful Wake Up Sid which was so simple in itself that even flying birds will look somewhat more complex in front of it and it became the USP of Wake Up Sid.But here Ayan is taking YJHD to a commercial level by selecting heavy locations,adding glamour and using chart busters which weren't there in Wake Up Sid.This ultimately transfers the bar to the other side which the movie was making.

Nevertheless,the movie does take you to a joyride in the first half and in bits and pieces in the second half.Some truly fun moments are there which really are worth mentioning.The chumma chumma de de sequence,aditi(kalki)-so-desperate-to-fight sequence and Ranbir-flirting sequences. The performance of Ranbir is a not-much-not-less kind of performance.It's an appropriate mix of a charmer,a believer,a good dancer and a dream follower.Deepika is so good in her Geek-naina,Independent-Naina and Lover-Naina character.A genuine performance by her.Kalki is so much fun each and every time she appears. The new pjyakkar and sharabi of Bollywood has arrived.He(Aditya Roy Kapoor) should learn how to control his facial expression while delivering his dialogues rather than doing roles of a sharabi.Faarooq Sheikh is awesome in his cameo. But the real hero or rather star of YJHD is Pritam Chakraborty.His compositions are sometimes rocking and sometimes so soulful that stands tall or even compromises for some dull moments in the movie.Hats Off to the Genius.Chart busters such as Badtameez Dil,Ghaghra,Dilliwali Girlfriend and soulful tracks like Shubhanallah,Kabira and Illahi are there.The music is for the classes as well as the masses. The movie suffers too much while giving messages which needed a deft touch.Inspite of some fun moments there really are less no. of high points in the movie.

It could've been a much better movie if they had done some more work on the script.Watch it for it's Music,Ranbir-Deepika and last but not the least Madhuri's comeback.
Words can't explain how much I loved this movie... definitely a 'must watch' movie...

Only thing I would complain is the movie name. Why could not they come up with some beautiful name for this beautiful movie instead of something silly like this.

I had not watched this movie earlier thinking it is one of those Ranbir movies with light story. But I was simply amazed by watching it.

The first part of movie so instantly connects us to the deepika's character. Deepika is such a superb actor and so gorgeous. And it simply drives us through some magic moments, those moments are though exaggerated as part of dharma movie but we can relate to.

And 2nd part of movie, we find ourselves more inverted in Ranbir's character. This movie is such a breeze to watch. Emotionally full of love and feel good moments. And ranbir's scene at the end touched me. It is really feel good movie.

Both Ranbir and Deepika nailed in the movie. But deepika looks more natural.
A movie that you can watch over and over again..!!

This movie was so bad it compelled me to warn others and to write my first review.Can't imagine that a USD 8 Million could be spent on such rubbish let alone it appalls when some thing of this nature hits a usd 48 Million on box office.This was my first movie of Ranbir Kapoor and Ayan Mukharji and both didn't give me that important first impression.I wanted to deliberately have patience to give it a chance to take something out of it but it was just down hill.There was no likability factor about Bunny's character and I don't have a clue as to why Naina should fall for him.It wasn't the same Deepika Pandukone I saw in Chennai Express either.Neither it gave me laughter nor tears but left with an emotionless soul through out.So naive to think that problems can be solved by a mere kiss and it really pisses me off. Message conveyed is completely out of my moral compass. Humor was just mediocre.All in all this is miles away at best compared with movies in the caliber of "Veer Zaara","Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge" "Qayamat Se Qayamat Tak".When a movie is intriguing it ends so fast as I am not conscience about time but after 45 minutes of this movie I felt many times stop watching it.Please Mr Ayan Mukherji you have a lot to take from your producer Karan Johar's books.

review_title: Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani is a 2013 Indian coming-of-age romantic comedy film.

"Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is a vibrant coming-of-age film that seamlessly blends friendship, love, and self-discovery. With a dynamic cast led by Ranbir Kapoor and Deepika Padukone, the movie strikes a perfect balance between heartwarming moments and energetic celebrations. Ayan Mukerji's direction, coupled with Pritam's memorable music, creates a visually stunning and emotionally resonant cinematic experience. "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" is a delightful journey that captures the essence of youth, making it a must-watch for those seeking romance, laughter, and a touch of nostalgia.

The narrative seamlessly weaves together heartfelt moments, humor, and emotional depth, making it a delightful cinematic journey. "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" stands out as a refreshing and relatable story that resonates with audiences, leaving a lasting impression.

If fun is what you're looking for, and have the patience to sit through a long movie, then this one is for you. Directed by Ayan Mukerji, whose last venture was the impressive Wake Up Sid, Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani has all the elements required to make a good film. However, Ayan falters way too often, both with the screenplay and direction, which make YJHD just an average film. The story has shades of Dil Chahta Hai, Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara and 3 Idiots, but it does not charm you like any of those. I thought the screenplay was mediocre.

Nevertheless, a decent one time watch. Deepika and Ranbir sizzle up the screen, while the rest of the cast does a good job. On the downside, a shorter film with better screenplay would have been more effective.

Acting: 8.5/10 Story-Screenplay-Direction: 7.5/10 Technical Aspects: 7/10

Verdict: 8/10

Peter_Young17 September 2021 6/10 Enjoyable but pretty much a rehash Ayan Mukerji previously directed Wake Up Sid, his directorial debut, and he did a wonderful job with a film that was both refreshing and very good in and of itself. Just as it often goes with second ventures of promising first-timers, his next film, Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani, is nowhere as good. I knew nothing about this film when I started watching it except that it was an extraordinary mainstream success. But I was quite interested in watching it. The film is not bad at all, but it just doesn't live up the hype it seeks to generate at its core premise.

The film follows four youngsters in one of their last trips together before one of them leaves the country. While the film is beautifully shot and is a thoroughly enjoyable watch, it's never more than pleasant, it's never overwhelming, and there's hardly any reminiscence of what the title prepared us for - you'll see none of the youth craze or even youth culture that you would probably immediately associate with this film, and what is lacking at the heart of an otherwise watchable film is the much called-for wild spirit which Mukherjee doesn't manage to capture.

And it's not that Mukerji doesn't try. He does. There are some scenes of running through the markets, there are catchy songs and pretty girls, but the script often makes the story not ring true. The only portion where it leaves a mark is in the relationship between the two friends who meet after many years. The romantic tension between the two leads does work to a point, but sometimes it's too polished and fairy tale-like to really be impactful. And the biggest problem, it mostly just feels a rehash of previous films. At points the references to old Dharma (the production company under which the film is produced) films, people, and songs, is really pathetic.

The film's characters are merely derivative of previous famous characters, and are never given enough depth. Ranbir Kapoor repeats his Wake Up Sid character, and he does it well although it feels he never allows himself to shed all his inhibitions. Aditya Roy Kapur is exceedingly good in some parts and struggles in others, while Kalki is wasted although she is consistently good. The winner of course is Deepika. Again, her character is just a recap of popular characters (Kajol's Anjali in Kuch Kuch Hota Hai; Preity Zinta's Naina in Kal Ho Naa Ho), but she is wonderful, subtly conveying much through her expressive eyes and the tiny, nuanced gestures on her pretty face.

Towards the end, the film grows incresingly fluffy, corny and starry, much to the point of losing the lighthearted nature it sought to define back in the beginning of the show. Heavy music and numerous sentimental scenes are followed by a most shallow moment of realisation on the part of the male protagonist, which is not convincing enough. Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani is not bad, I have no doubt some would highly enjoy it. Actually I enjoyed it too, I just expected more from this film and was disappointed. Still so, it is watchable and entertaining, with some nice romantic and musical portions.

arupghose16 November 2013 8/10 A film that will make you want to fall in love I'm watching this film well after it was released in the cinemas (in fact after seeing both Besharam and Chennai Express) so I know how the film had performed at the box office, and what most people thought of it so my expectations were high!

YJHD does through the typical roller coaster of a Bollywood romance, but where it differs from those that have failed, is that it has the star power of Ranbir and Deepika at the top of their game, alongside lovely music by Pritam and fantastic direction by Ayan Mukherjee.

Ayan is certainly one of the top young directors in the industry, and after Wake Up Sid, shows exactly why he holds his mantle piece. This work will go down as one of his finest, even though I am sure he will make many more films.

This role is bread and butter for someone of Ranbir's stature now. He eases into the role, initially playing the fun going flirty young man, then growing into the serious, yet romantic mature man later. This role is not on the same level as Barfi, there is no comparison, however it's these types of roles that will keep Ranbir competing with the likes of SRK for the romantic king award! Deepika has grown massively this year, and this being the third film (Ram Leela is the 4th) she has hit the industry with a bang in 2013. She looks stunning on screen and plays her role perfectly! Kalki, as annoying as her role, again plays it without any blemishes. Her role reminds you of Zindagi Na Milenge Dobara quite a lot! Aditya seems to be alcoholic of 2013 with this and Aashiqui 2 but does full justice to the role regardless!

Another massive plus point to the film Pritam's music. It's soulful throughout and adds a lot to the film. Kabira, Ilahi and Balam Picharki are my favourites.

Overall YJHD is a beautiful film with performances that will be hard to forget. It may not win any awards this year, but it will certainly will be a film I'll remember.

planktonrules14 October 2013 7/10 The story of Naina and Bunny has a few clichés, but it enjoyable and fun.

I enjoyed watching "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani" quite a bit, though I'll admit that the story has a few clichés here and there that kept it from being better. Still, given that I was watching it while flying across the Atlantic, it was a nice time-passer and kept my attention.

The film begins with Naina and her mother meeting up with a rather vacuous old schoolmate of Naina. While Naina graduated top of her class and is at the top of her class in medical school, this meeting with the schoolmate left Naina feeling that she's missing something...fun. So, on a lark, she decides to drop everything and head off on an adventure--and she picks the same destination the vacuous schoolmate chose. There, Naina slowly learns to unwind and meets sexy Bunny (he is a man--not some furry--despite the name). They hit it off and seem to be falling in love but one HUGE problem stands in their way--Bunny has vowed never to marry and wants to travel the world and experience EVERYTHING. What's to happen? See the film.

Like the typical Bollywood film, this romance is predictable and there's lots of singing. You can't fault the film for this--this is THE format that Indian films follow these days and very few deviate from this. My problem with the film, and it's minor, was the silly scene were Naina takes off her glasses and instantly people notice how hot she is! What a cliché....plus my wife was much like Naina when I met her but is hot with and without her glasses! Still, it's fun and worth seeing.

nairtejas31 May 2013 5/10 Ayan Mukherji Takes An Already Narrated Story & Adds Nothing To It... 50% Rating: 5/10

He takes up a ghissa-pita story, much like his debut Wake Up Sid and tries to turn it around. With the cast so heavily gorgeous giving out performances like its their last, revs up the movie-watching experience only for the first half. The second half sucks and drags a lot with cheeky references and illogical sequences. Overall, the route taken to say an old, short, romantic story, is arduous and infested with clichés as it dives into deep philosophy...

Traces of Dil Chahta Hai, Rang De Basanti, Kai Po Che & even Aashiqui 2 is explicit, so is the filmmaking which feels like they have been inspired by Zoya Akhtar. Even the screenplay is timid. The story is clichéd, yes, and to make it worse, the climax actually works against the film although it is justified for a theme like this. Unpredictability is stereotype here but Ayan molds it for his audience as a fun, frothy buddy flick which actually loses pace when theme of Rockstar & Karan Johar led family ties enter the plot.. Juxtaposed with heavy numbers, life elements, relationships, romance & social conflicts, Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani only appeals till midway.

Ranbir (who the film is almost based upon with the decisions he has to make as a complelling life of a nomad) & Deepike jazz up the screen with no mistake at all; yet Deepika's sudden shift from a pious, studious dame to her usual party- girl avatar is fishy , while Kalki & Aditya pass, with the script not letting them explore their insights. Kunaal is apt for the role while I still cannot construe what Poornima, Dixit & Rana were doing there. Revealing their characters may spoil the watch. Parental conflicts, much like in WUS is prevalent. Supporting cast (Farooq, Tanvi) is terrific. Music is brilliant and the locations add up to the movie-watching experience. At 165 minutes, the play seems to immensely go out of bounds, but the lead pair try hard and dishearteningly fail to keep us hooked. Emotions are played with and usual jealousy element brought up. Get a life, Ay.
